top_comment.text:
Colour sheep could've been improved:

Yellow
Black
Blue
Red
White

White + Black = Grey

White + Red = Pink

White + Blue = Turquoise

White + Yellow = Cream

Red + Yellow = Orange

Red + Black = Scarlet

Red + Blue = Purple

Black + Blue = Navy

Black + Yellow = Brown

Yellow + Blue = Green

Total colours:

Yellow
Black
Blue
Red
White
Grey
Pink
Turquoise
Cream
Orange
Scarlet
Purple
Navy
Brown
Green

I'm not try'na hate, I just think this makes more sense because it starts 
with the primary colours + black 'n white! (Colour sheep is still a pretty 
freakin' cool game)﻿

captions.text:
"I just wanna watch app all night, and now
you have me throwing chum in the water? You
Jerk."

[French accent] Ah, here we have the humble
sheep. Watch, as the predator approaches,
we see nature at work. LAZERRRSSSSSSS.

In Color Sheep you play Sir Woolson, who must
change his color in order to blast the flesh

off of wolves. This game becomes really difficult
as you have to quickly blend colors together

to match the incoming enemies in order to
fire a blast. The lasers are the fleecet of

their problems though because Sir Woolson
can also get insane power-ups. With a lot

of power could come some HueBrix, a really
fun puzzle game by Yellow Monkey Studios.

The grid needs to be filled completely with
the different colored brix, but what makes

this game really fun is the variety of modifiers.
There are ones that teleport your line, ones

that add more or less blocks, and ones that
force you to go into pre-determined directions.

But nothing will ever be as challenging as
Backflip Madness, one of the most frustratingly
difficult games I've ever played.

There is one button. Only one freaking button,
but Backflip Madness don't care. Backflip

Madness don't take nothin' from nobody. I'm
fairly certain that doing a backflip off of

a shipping container and over some oil drums
would be easier in real life. However, this

game is incredibly fun and addictive if only
because you keep trying again and again to

land that elusive perfect back flip. But if
you can't, let out your frustration by blowing
zombies away in Dead on Arrival.

This top-down shooter has you killing your
way through an undead-filled hospital. If

you've played Call of Duty Zombies then this
game will feel really familiar. The more you

annihilate, the more cash you get to buy a
better weapon off the wall, or to open new

areas. You even have to repair broken down
barricades. What makes Dead on Arrival really
cool is the graphic novel styled cut scenes.

But instead of painting the walls arterial
red with a shotgun, use PhotoViva. This image

editing app allows you to do basic photo correction,
but its coolest feature is the brushes. You

can paint over your images with different
brush types at different angles, and choose

what colors you want to pick up on so you
can create images like this:

Then test your memory with Trid. Recreate
the patterns quickly before you run out of

time. It seems easy enough until the board
you're suppose to replicate starts to rotate

and turn. But for something really infectious
there's Sporos.

In this awesome cellular puzzle game, you
have to place these Sporos across all of the

cells in the level. The lines in the Sporos
tell you which direction it will spread, and

you have to experiment with different placements
to find the most effective route for infection.

But instead of synthesizing and sequencing
scientifically, do it musically with Nanoloop,

a powerful music creation tool that is also
available for your Game Boy.

It has a sampler, sequencer, synth, and you
can modulate and manipulate to your heart's

content to create incredibly full-sounding
tunes. You can also share project files across

Android and iPhone to create something like
this:

Evac HD is the rave version of Pac-Man, but
in a good way. You collect dots and avoid

enemies that chase you, but instead of just
running from them, you can hide from them,

create traps, or just crush them. Just be
careful what path you take because a wrong

move might release swarms of villains that
ultimately lead to your demise.

But instead of running from your fears, face
them head on in this episode's app of the
week: Year Walk.

Year Walk is a beautiful, engaging, and creepy
adventure game. The main focus of the game

is puzzles and exploration with a heavy dose
of Swedish folk lore. The premise is that

you are on a vision quest, or, as the ancient
Swedes called it, a Year Walk, which, according

to legend, if successful, would allow you
to see the future. But in order to see the

future, you have to brave the woods and the
many creatures it holds. To add to the experience,

there is also a free companion app that gives
you the history behind the creatures and lore
you encounter in the game.

Links and prices can be found in the description
below.
I'm Jake and, as always, thanks for watching.
